review.title: Truthful Feedback for Sanctioning Reputation Mechanisms
review.abstract: For product rating environments, similar to that of Amazon Reviews, it has been shown that the truthful elicitation of feedback is possible through mechanisms which pay buyer reports contingent on the reports of other buyers. We study whether similar mechanisms can be designed for reputation mechanisms at online auction sites where the buyers' experiences are partially determined by a strategic seller. We show that this is impossible for the basic setting. However, introducing a small prior belief that the seller is a cooperative commitment player leads to a payment scheme with a truthful perfect Bayesian equilibrium.

We show that this is impossible in the underlying environment. However, the introduction of a small prior belief that the seller is a cooperative, engaged actor leads to a payment scheme with truly perfect Bayesian equilibrium.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The essential distinction between these two roles of behavior is the nature of the cooperation between the auction houses: books and electronic devices are ordered by Amazon1, used items are traded on eBay2, and services are offered on independent portals, such as Elance3. Almost every e-commerce site uses a so-called reputation mechanism that collects and publishes customer reviews, and it is instructive to distinguish between different types of reputation mechanisms that they collect and publish in accordance with the role they play: those employed by online opinion forums such as Amazon Reviews or Ciao4 are built to eliminate asymmetrical information from their customers. They are called signaling mechanisms, since they collect and publish feedback on the quality of products, signaling the previously hidden quality of future customers. sections.heading: 2 THE MODEL
sections.text: Before we examine the design space of feedback mechanisms for online auction sites, we explain the basic procedure together with the game theory model.

sections.heading: 2.1 PROCEDURE
sections.text: The idealized approach of a single transaction is as follows: The seller describes the quality of a good he wants to sell and interested customers submit their bids. At some point, the auction platform determines the buyer who then pays for the good. Once payment is received, the seller sends it in the prescribed quality. Unfortunately, this idealized procedure is prone to fraud: since the buyer must pay the good before the seller sends it, the seller is better off through fraud, i.e. either not at all or in a lower quality than described. In anticipation, the buyer does not pay for the good at all. This is called a dilemma because it leads to a non-trade situation, even if both buyer and seller benefit from the trade if the seller could credibly commit to cooperate. In the following, we limit ourselves to environments with numerous expenditures but only binary signals. The interpretation of a signal is whether the contract, i.e. the description of the good together with the promise to send it, has been fulfilled.

sections.heading: 2.2 SELLER BEHAVIOR
sections.text: We typically assume for the sanction mechanisms that the seller is a long-term player facing a sequence of short-term buyers, i.e. buyers who are interested in the seller's product in a one-step game only. Each buyer responds best to the seller's belief in the seller's action. That is, a buyer decides to pay for the good when the belief that the seller is cooperating exceeds a certain threshold. In the usual literature on reputation mechanism design, the efficiency of a design is evaluated by deriving upper or lower limits for the balance payout. Limitations are considered instead of actual balances, because it is not always clear which of several existing balances are chosen. Below, we assume that - given truthful feedback - the seller plays the balance that maximizes his payout. This is weakly justified, as some of the low payout balances are unreasonable: Once the buyer's feedback is asked for, the buyer's feedback is unreasonable.

sections.heading: 2.3 COMMITMENT TYPES
sections.text: Our game theory model of the online auction is that of Dellarocas (2005), expanded to include the possibility that players of cooperative "connection types" can be. Connection types have a long history in the game theory literature on reputation building: For example, Kreps and Wilson (1982) showed that - when the actions of long-term players are perfectly observed - a small early belief that the long-term player is committed to cooperation is sufficient to induce even a "strategic" long-term player to cooperate. The intuition behind this finding is that a strategic player "masks" himself as a committed player, that is, builds a reputation as a cooperative player. After a sufficiently long history of cooperative play, the belief of short-term players that the long-term player is a connection type is enough to approach 1 and they play the best response to cooperation. Fudenberg and Levine (1992) find a similar result for environments in which long-term players are only incompletely observed online as in the case of the auction.

sections.text: In order to get truthful feedback and get sellers to cooperate, we allow the mechanism to pay buyers for their feedback. Before we come to the description of the payment scheme, we clarify the applied solution concept and show how the conditional beliefs that the payment scheme requires can be calculated.

sections.heading: 4.2 FEASIBILITY ANALYSIS
sections.text: It is clear that LP 1 is limited as all factors in the objective function are not negative. To investigate if and when it is feasible, we first prove three lemmas, which ultimately enable us to prove our main message that LP 1 is feasible if and only if both types of sellers are more likely to do so. The intuition for this result is that if there is only one type of sellers whose strategies are generally considered to be prioritised, the belief of one buyer in the experience of another buyer does not change. sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have shown that the peer prediction method can be used to design a truthful feedback scheme for sanction mechanisms. Building on the literature on game theory and reputation building, we have introduced a binding seller who is fully cooperative and has shown that its existence is critical for the applicability of the methodology. In future work, we will reduce the conventional assumptions of our mechanism. In particular, we will modify the payment scheme so that instead of (possibly unknown) specific numbers, limits are taken into account in probabilistic parameters. For example, it should be sufficient to know that high sales efforts are followed by a high signal with a probability of at least 90%. Another difficulty in applying the mechanism is the assumption of a durable seller. We will therefore examine mechanisms that no longer rely on a long history of past feedback reports, but instead pay a seller an amount that is directly dependent on the reported quality and only after the transaction.

With regard to truthful feedback elicitation, signaling mechanisms are convenient because the perceived quality is essentially identical for all customers. Consider a digital camera bought via Amazon as an example: while different customers may experience different quality levels due to noise, they all receive the identical model.
